description: From Middle English esy, eesy, partly from Middle English ese (“ease”) + -y, equivalent to ease +‎ -y, and partly from Anglo-Norman eisé from Old French aisié (“eased, at ease, at leisure”), past participle of aisier (“to put at ease”), from aise (“empty space, elbow room, opportunity”), of uncertain origin. See ease. Merged with Middle English ethe, eathe (“easy”), from Old English īeþe, from Proto-Germanic *auþuz, from Proto-Indo-European *h₂éwtus (“empty, lonely”), from Proto-Indo-European *h₂ew-. Compare also Old Saxon ōþi, Old High German ōdi, Old Norse auðr, all meaning "easy, vacant, empty." More at ease, eath.

adjectives.description: easy (comparative easier or more easy, superlative easiest or most easy)

entries.meaning: (now rare except in certain expressions) Comfortable; at ease.
examples: Now that I know it's taken care of, I can rest easy at night.
It's often easy to wake up but hard to get up.

entries.meaning: Causing ease; giving comfort, or freedom from care or labour.
examples: Rich people live in easy circumstances.

entries.meaning: Free from constraint, harshness, or formality; unconstrained; smooth.
(informal, derogatory, of a woman) Consenting readily to sex.
examples: She has a reputation for being easy; they say she slept with half the senior class.

entries.meaning: Not making resistance or showing unwillingness; tractable; yielding; compliant.
(finance, dated) Not straitened as to money matters; opposed to tight.
In a relaxed or casual manner.
examples: After his illness, John decided to take it easy.

entries.meaning: In a manner without strictness or harshness.
examples: Jane went easier on him after he broke his arm.
This project will cost 15 million dollars, easy.

verbs.description: easy (third-person singular simple present easies, present participle easying, simple past and past participle easied)
